definitions.definition: the number of things or people that a container or space can hold

examples.text: a fuel tank with a maximum capacity of 50 litres
The theatre has a seating capacity of 2 000.
a hard disk **storage capacity **of 1 000 gigabytes
large-capacity disk drives
The hall was **filled to capacity** *(= was completely full)*.
They played to a **capacity crowd** *(= one that filled all the space or seats)*.

definitions.definition: the ability to understand or to do something
definitions.sensetop: capacity for somethingcapacity for doing somethingcapacity to do somethingbeyond/within somebody's capacity

examples.text: mental/intellectual capacity
She has an enormous capacity for hard work.
Limited resources are restricting our capacity for developing new products.
A habit becomes an addiction when it reduces your capacity to enjoy life.
The mountain walk is well within the capacity of most fit people.
His capacity for learning languages astonished me.
She seems to have lost the capacity to enjoy herself.
These questions are beyond the capacity of most students.
The qualification should increase my earning capacity.

definitions.definition: the official position or function that somebody has
definitions.sensetop: in a… capacityin your capacity as something

examples.text: We are simply involved in an **advisory capacity** on the project.
to do something in a business/judicial/professional/voluntary capacity
She was acting **in her capacity as** manager.
In my capacity as president, I would like to thank Jack for his hard work.

definitions.definition: the quantity that a factory, machine, etc. can produce

examples.text: The downturn in the business cycle left the plant with **excess capacity**.
Spare oil **production capacity** will probably remain low.
The factory is working **at (full) capacity**.

definitions.definition: the size or power of a piece of equipment, especially the engine of a vehicle

examples.text: an engine with a capacity of 1 600 cc

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from French capacité, from Latin capacitas, from capax, capac- ‘that can contain’, from capere ‘take or hold’.
